(c) Subject to Section 7(d), and subject to the prior written consent of the Agent so long as the Loan Agreement remains outstanding, the Owner may remove the Servicer immediately upon written notice of termination from the Owner to the Servicer if any of the following events shall occur (each, a "Servicer Termination Right - Owner"):

(i) the Servicer shall default in the performance of any of its duties under this Agreement and, after notice of such default, shall not cure such default within 30 days (or, if such default cannot be cured in such time, shall not give within 30 days such assurance of cure as shall be reasonably satisfactory to the Owner); or
perturbation.changed_text:
(c) Subject to Section 7(d), and subject to the prior written consent of the Agent so long as the Loan Agreement remains outstanding, the Owner may remove the Servicer immediately upon written notice of termination from the Owner to the Servicer if any of the following events shall occur (each, a "Servicer Termination Right - Owner"):

(i) the Servicer shall default in the performance of any of its duties under this Agreement and, after notice of such default, shall not cure such default within 10 days (or, if such default cannot be cured in such time, shall not give within 10 days such assurance of cure as shall be reasonably satisfactory to the Owner); or
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a default from 30 days to 10 days may be considered unreasonable and contradict general principles of contract law, potentially violating good faith and fair dealing implied in contracts. Many jurisdictions require a reasonable cure period, and 10 days might be deemed insufficient, especially for complex defaults.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding good faith and fair dealing, potentially violating state-specific contract laws regarding reasonable cure periods.

perturbation.original_text: The Servicer agrees that if any of the events specified in clause (ii) of this Section 7(c) shall occur, it shall give written notice thereof to the Owner within seven (7) days after the occurrence of such event.
perturbation.changed_text: The Servicer agrees that if any of the events specified in clause (ii) of this Section 7(c) shall occur, it shall give written notice thereof to the Owner within one (1) day after the occurrence of such event.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for bankruptcy or insolvency events from seven days to one day may be considered an unreasonably short timeframe, potentially hindering the Servicer's ability to accurately assess and report the situation. This could violate principles of reasonable notice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding reasonable notice, potentially violating state-specific contract laws.

perturbation.original_text: (b) Subject to Section 7(d), the Servicer may resign its duties hereunder by providing the Owner with at least 60 days' prior written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: (b) Subject to Section 7(d), the Servicer may resign its duties hereunder by providing the Owner with at least 15 days' prior written notice.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for resignation from 60 days to 15 days could be deemed an insufficient timeframe for the Owner to find a suitable replacement and ensure a smooth transition of servicing responsibilities. This may violate the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing, especially if finding a replacement servicer takes longer than 15 days.
